grammar.front_text: Nouns refer to people, places or things. Ideas and thoughts are things too!
Pronouns are words that replace nouns. The thing (or person, or place) that the pronoun refers to needs to have been mentioned already by name somewhere earlier in the sentence or paragraph!
grammar.examples: I swam in the ocean. You swam in the ocean.

grammar.front_text: Adjectives are descriptive words that add detail to a sentence. They are used to describe nouns, that we just learnt!
Verbs are action words, and tell you what the subject(described by a noun or pronoun) is doing.

Adverbs describe verbs, adjectives, or even a whole sentence. Adverbs often end with the suffix -ly. Some look the same as their adjective forms, however, such as fast. Watch out for these exceptions!
grammar.examples: He did badly for his test. I strongly disagreed with her.

grammar.front_text: Articles are words that come before a noun, to describe it. There are 2 different articles - the and a. 'The' means the noun is not specific, while 'a' means the noun is specific!
grammar.examples: The wind is strong today. A visitor came to my house today.

grammar.front_text: Prepositions are little words that tell where or when something is.
grammar.examples: The monkey is on his back. The glue is behind the board.

grammar.front_text: Conjunctions are words that connect sentences together, such as and, but and or.
grammar.examples: I wanted to meet her there on time, but I got stuck in traffic. You can’t wear socks and sandals.

grammar.front_text: Verbs come in past, present, and future tenses. The past is describes things that already happened. The present tense describes things that are happening right now, and the future tense describes things that have yet to happen.
grammar.examples: Past tense - I lived here when I was ten. Present tense - I live here now. Future tense - I will live there when I am retired.

grammar.front_text: Singular subjects should take singular verbs, while plural subjects should take plural verbs.
grammar.examples: My brother is a doctor. My parents areyoga teachers.

plants and animals.front_text: A 3 stage life-cycle for animals consists of the egg, young and adult stage.
plants and animals.examples: In the picture, a grasshopper goes from the egg, nymph to finally the adult stage.

plants and animals.front_text: A 4 stage life-cycle for animals consists of the egg, larva, pupa and adult stage.
plants and animals.examples: In the picture, a butterfly goes from the egg, to a larva(caterpillar), where it becomes a pupa to reach the adult stage.

plants and animals.front_text: Cold-blooded animals are unable to regulate their body's temperature according to the temperature of the surroundings. Warm-blooded animals are able to maintain a nearly constant body temperature, in almost any environment
plants and animals.examples: Reptiles, Amphibians, Fish and Insects are cold-blooded. Mammals, birds, and some fish and insects are warm-blooded.

plants and animals.front_text: For a flowering plant, the seed first germinates under sufficient water, warmth and oxygen, grows into a seedling, then young plant. The plant bears flowers then fruit in the adult stage.
plants and animals.examples: In the picture, the life cycle of a flowering plant is mainly split into 5 parts.

plants and animals.front_text: After seed germination, the roots, then shoot grows out. The seedling depends on the seed coat for food before developing leaves.
plants and animals.examples: In the picture, the development of a seed to a young plant is shown.

plants and animals.front_text: A plant has many parts that perform different functions. The picture shows the different functions of these parts.
Photosynthesis is the process by which plants turn water, sunlight, and carbon dioxide into water, oxygen, and simple sugars
plants and animals.examples: The diagram shows the process of photosynthesis in more detail.

plants and animals.front_text: There are five main modes of seed dispersal: by gravity, wind, explosion, water, and animals.
plants and animals.examples: The diagram shows examples of plants that have different seed dispersal methods.

plants and animals.front_text: There are six basic animal groups: fish, amphibians, reptiles, mammals, birds and invertaebrates.

In a food chain, there are food producers, organisms that make their own food, and food consumers, that consume food. A herbivore eats plants, an omnivore eats both plants and animals and a carnivore eats animals.
plants and animals.examples: The diagram shows a simple example of a food chain.

body systems, fungi and bacteria.front_text: The circulatory system consists of the heart, the blood and the blood vessels. It transports oxygen, digested food and water to the different parts of the body and at the same time, transports carbon dioxide and waste away from the different parts of the body for removal.
body systems, fungi and bacteria.examples: The diagram shows different parts of the circulatory system.

body systems, fungi and bacteria.front_text: The skeletal system consists of all the bones in our body. It provides support to our body, protects our important organs and work together with the muscular system to enable movement.
body systems, fungi and bacteria.examples: The diagram shows how the skeletal system looks like.

body systems, fungi and bacteria.front_text: The respiratory system consists of the nose, windpipe and the lungs. It helps take in oxygen that our body needs for survival, and give out carbon dioxide
body systems, fungi and bacteria.examples: The diagram shows the different parts of the respiratory system.

body systems, fungi and bacteria.front_text: The muscular system is made of different types of muscles.  Some muscles, like the muscles that are found on our arms and legs, can be controlled to enable movement. However, some muscles, such as those that make up our heart and stomach, cannot be controlled.
body systems, fungi and bacteria.examples: The diagram shows the different parts of the muscular system. Muscles work in pairs to enable movement.As one muscle contracts, the other muscle relaxes.

body systems, fungi and bacteria.front_text: The digestive system digests food into simpler substances and absorbs the digested food into the bloodstream. It consists of the mouth, the gullet, the stomach, the small intestine, the large intestine and the anus.
body systems, fungi and bacteria.examples: The diagram shows the different parts of the digestive system.

body systems, fungi and bacteria.front_text: Fungi are not plants as they do not have roots, stems or leaves.  A fungus is unable to make its own food as it does not have chlorophyll to trap sunlight for photosynthesis.
body systems, fungi and bacteria.examples: The diagram shows examples of fungi.

body systems, fungi and bacteria.front_text: There are some types of fungi we cannot see unless we use a microscope, such as yeast and mould.
body systems, fungi and bacteria.examples: The picture shows yeast and mould look under a microscope.

body systems, fungi and bacteria.front_text: Fungi are a type of decomposer. They obtain food by breaking down dead organisms into simpler substances though decomposition and absorb the simple substances as food.
body systems, fungi and bacteria.examples: The picture shows the very important role fungi play in an ecosystem.

body systems, fungi and bacteria.front_text: Bacteria are microorganisms that we cannot usually see, unless we use a microscope. Some bacteria are helpful to us, while some are harmful to us.
body systems, fungi and bacteria.examples: The picture shows e-coli, a bacteria that causes us to fall sick.

body systems, fungi and bacteria.front_text: As with what we learned earlier about decomposers, bacteria are actually also decomposers, just like fungi!
body systems, fungi and bacteria.examples: After decomposition, nutrients are returned to the soil, so that plants can absorb those nutrients.

body systems, fungi and bacteria.front_text: Fungi reproduce by spores. For mushrooms, the spores are released from their gill cap.
body systems, fungi and bacteria.examples: The diagram shows spores of a mushroom in its gill cap.
